instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3435: What is 820-3435? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.P5VS4RS3_EN_R: What is P5VS4RS3_EN_R? P5VS4RS3_EN_R is an enable signal that turns on the PP5V_S4RS3 power rail. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. The _R means the signal is asserted when the voltage is high(3.3v). .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS? This is PPBUS_G3H after passing through a current sense resistor that splits it off from the rest of PPBUS_G3H. The purpose of this is so that we can measure how much current is flowing to this part of the machine..
definitions.P3V3S5_EN_R: What is P3V3S5_EN_R? P3V3S5_EN_R is an enable signal that turns on the PP3V3_S5 power rail.  Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. The _R means the signal is asserted when the voltage is high(3.3v). .
definitions.PP1V05_SO: What is PP1V05_SO? This is a typo of PP1V05_S0 When you see PP1V05_SO, assume they meant to type PP1V05_S0.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> 0.9v
threads.message:
dry board. Green light on charger CPU cold, no light on USB fan spinning.


Found exploded cap <CAPACITOR>C7600</CAPACITOR>
replaced it and <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> to be safe.
Checked for shorts to ground then tried powering. 
Get green light but no fan spin

Missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>
checked <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> was missing <SIGNAL>P5VS4RS3_EN_R</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>


<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 3.3  - OK
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> 0.9v - BAD

<RESISTOR>R1481</RESISTOR> measures 10k not 100k replaced it - STILL reads 10k.


Does this mean <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulled low by dead PCH ?

Grateful for any help.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> 0.9v
threads.message:
[QUOTE="MUUK, post: 22889"]

Does this mean <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulled low by dead PCH ?

[/QUOTE]

No not necessarily.

You've got more measuring and inspection to do.

So, you have <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> &, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> ?


There's plenty of paths to ground for <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> to escape other then through the PCH.

I would still look for corrosion somewhere, the amount of times I've found corrosion on a board that looked clean.......

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> 0.9v
threads.message:
0.9v is not a valid state. 3.3v makes sense. 0v makes sense. very quick, barely readable pulses from power cycling make sense. But 0.9v - that isn't valid at all.

Is <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> present?

<RESISTOR>R1481</RESISTOR> doesn't exist on this board. Either way, resistors used in these circuits fail to a higher resistance, not a lower resistance, so this doesn't count. Don't bother replacing resistors if they measure a lower resistance than their stated resistance and do not appear damaged. If something else is connecting point A to point B in other sections of the board you are measuring everything around the resistor as ell and of course if these paths exist you will see a lower resistance.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> 0.9v
threads.message:
My apologies. It was <RESISTOR>R1461</RESISTOR> mentioned incorrectly as <RESISTOR>R1481</RESISTOR> above. Thank you for telling me about the lower resistance.


started again and re-checked power rails today.




<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 8.6v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> 8.6v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL> 8.58v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.32v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 4.99v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.32v


<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> 0.03v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> 0v


<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 3.38v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>  0.19v (different to yesterday)


<CHIP>U7501</CHIP>

pin4 (EN1) 0.06v
pin23 (VIN) 8.6v
pin20 (<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 3.3v
pin21 (<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_R</SIGNAL>) 3.46v
pin 12 (<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>) 3.4v (this was missing yesterday)


So I have all S5 rails present, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is at 8.6 and the SMC seems to be working. 


Checking back on <SIGNAL>P5VS4RS3_EN_R</SIGNAL> 
<RESISTOR>R7551</RESISTOR> 0.04ohm
<RESISTOR>R8179</RESISTOR> 0.2ohm

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> at <RESISTOR>R8179</RESISTOR> 0.19v

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> 0.9v
threads.message: What is resistance to GND on <CAPACITOR>C7600</CAPACITOR>?

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> 0.9v
threads.message:
Hi Duke,

Resistance to ground (red probe on cap, black probe on gnd) starts 4.83kohm then rises quickly and keeps going.

Diode mode to ground (black probe on cap red probe on gnd) 0.455v drop.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> 0.9v
threads.message: Did some further checking. <CAPACITOR>C7601</CAPACITOR> and <SIGNAL>PP1V05_SO</SIGNAL> is shorted to ground. Removed <CAPACITOR>C7601</CAPACITOR> <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> and short is still present. Would this stop the machine going to S4 ?

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> 0.9v
threads.message: Lifted the coil L7630 - short is on system side (boo). Removed <CAPACITOR>C7623</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7648</CAPACITOR> & <CAPACITOR>C7649</CAPACITOR> short still present.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> 0.9v
threads.message: What is the resistance to ground on this rail???

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> 0.9v
threads.message:
Resistance to ground 0.9ohm. Diode mode 0v drop to ground.
If i lift the coil L7630 i get 0.9ohm system side (pin2) and 470k other side - which matches the reading on my donor board.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> 0.9v
[SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> 0.9v
threads.message: That was my suspicion. Appreciate the help and confirmation. (can mark as closed)
